articles.headline: China’s New Limits on Money Outflows Hit a Would-Be Paradise
articles.snippet: Based in Malaysia, Forest City promises clean air and beaches, but China’s efforts to keep money at home leave some buyers struggling to pay what they owe.
articles.abstract: Based in Malaysia, Forest City promises clean air and beaches, but China’s efforts to keep money at home leave some buyers struggling to pay what they owe.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s intensifying efforts to keep money from leaving the country have cast doubt over big Hollywood deals and other marquee investments.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Cao Li

articles.headline: Want Change? Shareholders Have a Tool for That
articles.snippet: With a new administration relaxing oversight, the prospect of curbing executive pay or forcing climate change accountability may fall to investors.
articles.abstract: With a new administration relaxing oversight, the prospect of curbing executive pay or forcing climate change accountability may fall to investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are you an investor who usually junks the voluminous corporate proxy statements that arrive each spring, declining to take part in director elections and other governance matters because you think your vote won’t count?

articles.headline: U.S. Investigating Mosul Strikes Said to Have Killed Up to 200 Civilians
articles.snippet: American military officials insisted that the rules of engagement had not changed in Iraq, despite a recent surge in reports of civilian deaths.
articles.abstract: American military officials insisted that the rules of engagement had not changed in Iraq, despite a recent surge in reports of civilian deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The American-led military coalition in Iraq said Friday that it was investigating reports that scores of civilians — perhaps as many as 200, residents said — had been killed in recent American airstrikes in Mosul, the northern Iraqi city at the center of an offensive to drive out the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: SeaWorld Stake, Long Held by Blackstone, Is Sold to Chinese Firm
articles.snippet: Blackstone sold its remaining shares in SeaWorld to Zhonghong for about $449 million, ending its ownership of the troubled theme park.
articles.abstract: Blackstone sold its remaining shares in SeaWorld to Zhonghong for about $449 million, ending its ownership of the troubled theme park.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over seven years, the Blackstone Group nearly tripled its investment in SeaWorld, the home of Shamu and other killer whales.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: California Upholds Auto Emissions Standards, Setting Up Face-Off With Trump
articles.snippet: The backing of rules adopted in the Obama administration is one of the most direct moves so far to blunt President Trump’s effort to roll back regulations.
articles.abstract: The backing of rules adopted in the Obama administration is one of the most direct moves so far to blunt President Trump’s effort to roll back regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: California’s clean-air agency voted on Friday to push ahead with stricter emissions standards for cars and trucks, setting up a potential legal battle with the Trump administration over the state’s plan to reduce planet-warming gases.

articles.headline: Republicans Land a Punch on Health Care, to Their Own Face
articles.snippet: The big question for Republicans now is whether the Freedom Caucus, the party’s masters of destruction, will find themselves newly emboldened.
articles.abstract: The big question for Republicans now is whether the Freedom Caucus, the party’s masters of destruction, will find themselves newly emboldened.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the end of the long day, the alliance of conservative ideologues who once shut down the government over President Barack Obama’s health care law could not find the will to repeal it.

articles.headline: In Dropping Health Vote, Trump Swallowed Need for a Showdown
articles.snippet: The demise of the bill played out in a tense 24 hours that White House and congressional officials said proved a political education for President Trump and his top advisers.
articles.abstract: The demise of the bill played out in a tense 24 hours that White House and congressional officials said proved a political education for President Trump and his top advisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Speaker Paul D. Ryan arrived at the White House on Friday to inform President Trump that the health care bill he had made his first major legislative push could not pass, Mr. Trump had one reaction: He wanted revenge.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Amazon’s Ambitions Unboxed: Stores for Furniture, Appliances and More
articles.snippet: The online retailing giant is trying to bring its own formula to traditional retailing. If it is successful, it could change how all stores operate.
articles.abstract: The online retailing giant is trying to bring its own formula to traditional retailing. If it is successful, it could change how all stores operate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Last Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif., Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, climbed into the cockpit of a 13-foot robot and began flailing his arms as though warming up for a workout, causing the robot’s enormous appendages to mimic his movements.

articles.headline: Canadians Adopted Refugee Families for a Year. Then Came ‘Month 13.’
articles.snippet: Everyday Canadians spent a year embracing Syrians in the world’s most personal resettlement program. Letting them go might be the biggest test yet.
articles.abstract: Everyday Canadians spent a year embracing Syrians in the world’s most personal resettlement program. Letting them go might be the biggest test yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — One year after Canada embraced Syrian refugees like no other country, a reckoning was underway.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn

articles.headline: Trump Becomes Ensnared in Fiery G.O.P. Civil War
articles.snippet: The health bill’s defeat leaves the president facing a wrenching choice: ceding power to his party’s anti-establishment wing, or seeking other pathways to successful governing.
articles.abstract: The health bill’s defeat leaves the president facing a wrenching choice: ceding power to his party’s anti-establishment wing, or seeking other pathways to successful governing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ignites a lot of fights, but his failure to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the biggest defeat in his short time in the White House, was the result of something else: a long-running Republican civil war that humbled a generation of party leaders before he ever came to Washington.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Emerges From Health Care Defeat Badly Damaged
articles.snippet: He is now tasked with defending not just his leadership abilities but his very brand of conservatism in a party fitfully searching for a coherent policy identity.
articles.abstract: He is now tasked with defending not just his leadership abilities but his very brand of conservatism in a party fitfully searching for a coherent policy identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For two days in January, all seemed right in the Republican Party.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: North Korea’s Rising Ambition Seen in Bid to Breach Global Banks
articles.snippet: An attack late last year targeting more than 20 Polish banks suggests that hackers linked to North Korea are becoming more sophisticated and brazen.
articles.abstract: An attack late last year targeting more than 20 Polish banks suggests that hackers linked to North Korea are becoming more sophisticated and brazen.
articles.lead_paragraph: When hackers associated with North Korea tried to break into Polish banks late last year they left a trail of information about their apparent intentions to steal money from more than 100 organizations around the world, according to security researchers.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Health Bill’s Failure Leaves Supporters in a Political Jam Back Home
articles.snippet: In running for re-election next year, some Republican lawmakers may have to defend their support for a politically explosive bill that many backed only reluctantly.
articles.abstract: In running for re-election next year, some Republican lawmakers may have to defend their support for a politically explosive bill that many backed only reluctantly.
articles.lead_paragraph: They went to unusual, even dangerous lengths to support President Trump’s unpopular health care bill, facing down protesters at home and begging for special accommodation from House leaders in Washington. John Faso of New York negotiated a side deal for his state in exchange for backing it. Mike Coffman was the lone Colorado lawmaker to endorse the bill, while his Republican neighbors agonized and stalled.

articles.headline: Who Killed the Iceman? Clues Emerge in a Very Cold Case
articles.snippet: Using a wealth of new scientific information, a seasoned homicide detective has developed a theory in a death 5,300 years ago.
articles.abstract: Using a wealth of new scientific information, a seasoned homicide detective has developed a theory in a death 5,300 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOLZANO, Italy — When the head of a small Italian museum called Detective Inspector Alexander Horn of the Munich Police, she asked him if he investigated cold cases.

articles.headline: Brands Try to Blacklist Breitbart, but Ads Slip Through Anyway
articles.snippet: Companies have difficulty controlling where their ads appear because of the largely automated nature of online advertising.
articles.abstract: Companies have difficulty controlling where their ads appear because of the largely automated nature of online advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the presidential election, hundreds of companies have decided to block their advertisements from running on Breitbart News, the alt-right website closely tied to President Trump’s administration. But several of those brands, from the Nordstrom department store chain to small start-ups, have appeared on the site anyway, another example of how little control companies often have over where their ads are seen online.

articles.headline: Push for Internet Privacy Rules Moves to Statehouses
articles.snippet: As Congress acts to roll back regulations limiting access to consumer data, several states are considering laws that could have a wide impact.
articles.abstract: As Congress acts to roll back regulations limiting access to consumer data, several states are considering laws that could have a wide impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that Republicans are in charge, the federal government is poised to roll back regulations limiting access to consumers’ online data. States have other ideas.

articles.headline: Icahn Raises Ethics Flags With Dual Roles as Investor and Trump Adviser
articles.snippet: The billionaire is advising on regulations, including pressing for a change in an E.P.A. rule that has cost an oil refinery he’s invested in millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: The billionaire is advising on regulations, including pressing for a change in an E.P.A. rule that has cost an oil refinery he’s invested in millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since Carl Icahn, the billionaire investor, was named by President Trump as a special adviser on regulatory matters, he has been busy working behind the scenes to try to revamp an obscure Environmental Protection Agency rule that governs the way corn-based ethanol is mixed into gasoline nationwide.

articles.headline: A Rare Venture Capitalist — Female and Retail-Focused
articles.snippet: Kirsten Green is unusual for a number of reasons: She never worked at a venture capital firm before starting her own, and she’s a woman in a male-dominated field.
articles.abstract: Kirsten Green is unusual for a number of reasons: She never worked at a venture capital firm before starting her own, and she’s a woman in a male-dominated field.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Kirsten Green had only dabbled in investing in start-ups before she began a venture capital fund in 2012. What she had instead was years of experience covering the retail business as an analyst on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: The Weekly Standard’s Arsenal to Fight Falsehoods: ‘Facts, Logic and Reason’
articles.snippet: After a decades-long project to undercut the mainstream news media, some right-leaning organizations are pushing back, our media columnist writes.
articles.abstract: After a decades-long project to undercut the mainstream news media, some right-leaning organizations are pushing back, our media columnist writes.
articles.lead_paragraph: “When the going gets weird, the weird turn pro.”

articles.headline: Dealt a Defeat, Republicans Set Their Sights on Major Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: Congressional Republicans face a challenge made more difficult by the collapse of their health care bill, and may have to scale back their grand plans.
articles.abstract: Congressional Republicans face a challenge made more difficult by the collapse of their health care bill, and may have to scale back their grand plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Picking themselves up after the bruising collapse of their health care plan, President Trump and Republicans in Congress will start this week on a legislative obstacle course that will be even more arduous: the first overhaul of the tax code in three decades.

articles.headline: ‘Why Do All the Jihadis Come to Birmingham?’
articles.snippet: Birmingham, Britain’s second-largest city, with a large Muslim population, has become known as a recruiting ground. Muslim residents resent the stigma but acknowledge the problem.
articles.abstract: Birmingham, Britain’s second-largest city, with a large Muslim population, has become known as a recruiting ground. Muslim residents resent the stigma but acknowledge the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — Outside the Maasha’Allah internet cafe, Mohammed Hussain raised his voice over the recorded Quranic verses blaring from the abaya shop two doors down. He was furious that Britain’s latest terrorist attacker had amplified his city’s stigma.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

articles.headline: Democrats, Buoyed by G.O.P. Health Defeat, See No Need to Offer Hand
articles.snippet: The party, in its best position since its loss in the November election, is newly optimistic about picking up seats in 2018, hoping to ride a backlash against President Trump.
articles.abstract: The party, in its best position since its loss in the November election, is newly optimistic about picking up seats in 2018, hoping to ride a backlash against President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, looking for a flicker of hope after his Republican majority fell to pieces last week, predicted that the opposition party would eventually give in: “I honestly believe the Democrats will come to us and say let’s get together and get a great health care bill or plan,” he said.

articles.headline: In Rare Move, Chinese Think Tank Criticizes Tepid Pace of Reform
articles.snippet: Efforts to overhaul the world’s No. 2 economy have “fallen into stalemate,” contends a report that chastises national policy makers and local officials.
articles.abstract: Efforts to overhaul the world’s No. 2 economy have “fallen into stalemate,” contends a report that chastises national policy makers and local officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s ambitious plan to revamp its economy has bogged down. Flabby state conglomerates have thwarted attempts to whip them into commercial shape. Rules that treat millions of city-dwelling rural migrants like second-class citizens have barely budged.

articles.headline: Senate Committee to Question Jared Kushner Over Meetings With Russians
articles.snippet: The president’s son-in-law faces questions about meetings he arranged with the Russian ambassador, including a sit-down with the head of Russia’s state-owned development bank.
articles.abstract: The president’s son-in-law faces questions about meetings he arranged with the Russian ambassador, including a sit-down with the head of Russia’s state-owned development bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senate investigators plan to question Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and a close adviser, as part of their broad inquiry into ties between Trump associates and Russian officials or others linked to the Kremlin, according to administration and congressional officials.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker, Matthew Rosenberg and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Stocks Briefly Tumble After Health Care Overhaul Falters
articles.snippet: With new doubts from investors about items on the Trump agenda, shares opened sharply lower before the market recovered to end the day little changed.
articles.abstract: With new doubts from investors about items on the Trump agenda, shares opened sharply lower before the market recovered to end the day little changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a time on Monday, one question appeared to haunt stock market investors from Tokyo to Manhattan: Will President Trump be able to live up to his promises to reduce taxes and cut regulation?
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Alexandra Stevenson
